comments: Kurepa's conjecture is that (!n,n!)=2, n>1. It is easy to prove that this is equivalent to showing that (p,!p)=1 for all odd primes p. In Guy, 2nd edition, it is stated that Mijajlovic has tested up to p=10^6. Subsequently Gallot tested up to 2^26. I have continued up to just above p=2^27, in fact to p<144000000. There were no examples found where (p, !p)>1. - Paul Jobling, Dec 02 2004According to Kellner, the conjecture has been proved by Barsky and Benzaghou. - _T. D. Noe_, Dec 02 2004Barsky and Benzaghou withdrew their proof in 2011. I've extended the search up to 10^9, counterexample wasn't found. - _Milos Tatarevic_, Feb 01 2013
